item.title: Los Angeles Has America’s Most Important Orchestra. Period.
item.media:description: The Icelandic rock band Sigur Ros performing with the Los Angeles Philharmonic.
item.description: Our critic finds that an inspiring leader has left the Los Angeles Philharmonic in peerless artistic shape.
item.dc:creator: ZACHARY WOOLFE

item.title: How Prince Concealed His Addiction: Aspirin Bottles of Opiates
item.media:description: Prince, who died last April at the age of 57, was concealing an addiction to opiates, according to investigators.
item.description: Newly released court documents reveal that the singer’s home was strewn with narcotic painkillers for which he did not have prescriptions.
item.dc:creator: JOE COSCARELLI and SERGE F. KOVALESKI

item.title: Review: Kendrick Lamar’s Anxiety Leads to Joy and Jabs on New Album
item.media:description: Kendrick Lamar at the Music Hall of Williamsburg in December.
item.media:credit: Bryan Bedder/Getty Images for American Express
item.description: The rapper reflects on interior concerns on his “tart and punchy” fourth studio album, “DAMN.”
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA

item.title: A Word With: After a Half-Century in Music, Clive Davis Is Still in Love
item.media:description: Clive Davis’s long career in the music business is the subject of a documentary opening the Tribeca Film Festival: “Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives.”
item.media:credit: Bryan Derballa for The New York Times
item.description: This executive’s long career is the subject of a new documentary, “Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives.”
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO
item.category: Clive Davis: The Soundtrack of Our Lives (Movie)

item.title: Allan Holdsworth, Virtuoso Guitarist, Dies at 70
item.media:description: Allan Holdsworth performing with the progressive rock group U.K. in Central Park in 1978.
item.description: Mr. Holdsworth, whose talent amazed better-known peers like Frank Zappa and Eddie Van Halen, played in seminal bands including Soft Machine before making a series of solo albums.
item.dc:creator: GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: Sylvia Moy, Songwriter Who Worked With Stevie Wonder, Dies at 78
item.media:description: Sylvia Moy and Stevie Wonder, with, behind from left, James Jamerson, Earl Van Dyke and Robert White of the Funk Brothers, in 1967.
item.description: Ms. Moy was a Motown record producer who helped write hits like “My Cherie Amour” and “Uptight (Everything’s Alright).”
item.dc:creator: RICHARD SANDOMIR

item.title: Diamanda Galás Delves Into Darkness, Revisiting 8 Haunting Tracks
item.media:description: Diamanda Galás released two albums simultaneously in March, “All the Way” and “At Saint Thomas the Apostle Harlem.”
item.media:credit: Chad Batka for The New York Times
item.description: The avant-garde vocalist looks back at her nearly 40-year career as she releases two new albums.
item.dc:creator: ZACHARY WOOLFE
item.category: At Saint Thomas the Apostle Harlem (Album)

item.title: Alan Lomax Recordings Are Digitized in a New Online Collection
item.media:description: Alan Lomax, in 1992. As computer technology progressed, Lomax envisioned a searchable database for music from around the world.
item.media:credit: G. Paul Burnett/The New York Times
item.description: The project, the Global Jukebox, has more than 6,000 songs from 1,000 cultures — including many songs from Lomax’s personal collection.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW R. CHOW

item.title: Listen to the Young Soprano Who Is Winning Awards and Acclaim
item.media:description: The soprano Nadine Sierra, who has just won the 2017 Richard Tucker Award, in Mozart’s “Idomeneo” in March at the Metropolitan Opera.
item.media:credit: Hiroyuki Ito for The New York Times
item.description: Nadine Sierra, 28, started getting noticed when she was only in high school. Now she’s won the prestigious Richard Tucker Award and its $50,000 prize.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL COOPER

item.title: Concerts Celebrate Isang Yun, a Musical Bridge Between Asia and Europe
item.media:description: Isang Yun was born in what is now South Korea in 1917. He moved to West Berlin to study in 1957 and was later jailed in South Korea, but he eventually became a West German citizen.
item.description: Mr. Yun, a Korean composer who later lived in West Berlin, explored questions of identity. Events this season will mark the centenary of his birth.
item.dc:creator: REBECCA SCHMID

item.title: My Favorite Page: ‘It Demands Everything of You’: Alisa Weilerstein on Bach
item.media:description: Alisa Weilerstein in her dressing room at Boston Symphony Hall.
item.media:credit: Tony Luong for The New York Times
item.description: Ms. Weilerstein, set to perform all six of Bach’s solo cello suites in a single concert on Saturday, chooses her favorite page of the score.
item.dc:creator: DAVID ALLEN

item.title: Noted: Charlamagne Tha God Puts His Straight Talk in a Book
item.media:description: Charlamagne Tha God in the iHeartRadio offices in TriBeCa, where he is a co-host of “The Breakfast Club.”
item.media:credit: Andrew White for The New York Times
item.description: In “Black Privilege,” the radio and TV host recommends honesty as a form of self-empowerment.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN KURUTZ

item.title: Street Style: Coachella 2017
item.description: Scenes from the annual music and arts festival.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.category: Coachella Valley Music and Arts Festival

item.title: The Chainsmokers Prove They’re a Hit on the Album Chart, Too
item.media:description: Alex Pall, left, and Andrew Taggart of the Chainsmokers, whose “Memories...Do Not Open” debuted at No. 1 on the Billboard album charts.
item.description: The duo’s singles have performed well, and now its debut LP has opened at No. 1, bumping Drake’s “More Life” to No. 2.
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO

item.title: A ‘Carousel’ Revival Promises Stars, Onstage and Off
item.media:description: The stars of next season’s “Carousel” revival: from left, Jessie Mueller, Joshua Henry and Renée Fleming.
item.media:credit: From left: Ruth Fremson/The New York Times, Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times via Getty, and Damon Winter/The New York Times.
item.description: The cast includes Jessie Mueller, Joshua Henry and Renée Fleming, while New York City Ballet’s Justin Peck will choreograph.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL PAULSON

item.title: Bruce Langhorne, Guitarist Who Inspired ‘Mr. Tambourine Man,’ Dies at 78
item.media:description: Bruce Langhorne, far left, in an image from a YouTube video with Carolyn Hester, Bob Dylan and Bill Lee in 1961 in a studio in New York.
item.description: Mr. Langhorne played on many influential folk-rock albums, most notably Bob Dylan’s landmark “Bringing It All Back Home.”
item.dc:creator: BILL FRISKICS-WARREN

item.title: That Decisive Moment: Mozart, Made New: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
item.media:description: Dancers surround Erin Morley, left, as Sophie, and Elina Garanca as Octavian in “Der Rosenkavalier” at the Metropolitan Opera.
item.description: Mozart, Made New: This Week’s 8 Best Classical Music Moments
item.category: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (Play)

item.title: J. Cole, the Platinum Rap Dissident, Steps Back From the Spotlight
item.media:description: J. Cole has avoided the traditional life of a platinum rap star. In a new HBO special, he travels to cities that have personal or political resonance for him.
item.description: He’s a superstar rapper who has avoided the life of a superstar rapper. In a new HBO special, “J. Cole: 4 Your Eyez Only,” he shows fans what he’d rather think about.
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA

item.title: Playlist: The Playlist: Kamasi Washington Releases a Blast of ‘Truth’
item.media:description: "Truth," one of the tracks from Kamasi Washington's Whitney Biennial project "Harmony of Difference," came out online this week.
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.description: Hear the new songs that mattered this week, from Frank Ocean's collaboration with Jay Z to the latest from Amadou & Mariam.
item.dc:creator: JON PARELES, JON CARAMANICA and GIOVANNI RUSSONELLO

item.title: Bach’s ‘St. John Passion’ Has More Humanity Than Anti-Semitism
item.media:description: From left, the soprano Megan Chartrand and the flutists David Ross and Immanuel Davis performing Bach’s “St. John Passion” at St. Paul’s Chapel, Trinity Church.
item.description: The “St. John” has been accused of fanning bigotry, but judging from recent performances and recordings, it has much to teach us today.
item.dc:creator: JAMES R. OESTREICH

item.title: Critic's Notebook: With Politics as Backdrop, Hamburg’s New Hall Looks to America
item.media:description: The Venezuelan bass Iván García, center, performing Wednesday in the Transatlantik festival at the Elbphilharmonie in Hamburg.
item.media:credit: Gordon Welters for The New York Times
item.description: Several themed program clusters in the Elbphilharmonie’s sold-out opening season have focused attention on music from across the Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: CORINNA da FONSECA-WOLLHEIM

item.title: How Do You Solve a Problem Like the Chainsmokers?
item.media:description: Alex Pall, left, and Drew Taggart of the Chainsmokers. The duo’s first full album, “Memories…Do Not Open,” inches them closer to pop than dance music.
item.description: In three years, the duo has had several hits while offending all sorts of people. What does its sound say about EDM? A panel discussion, on Popcast.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Monterey Pop, the Rock Festival That Sparked It All, Returns
item.media:description: Janis Joplin performed with Big Brother and the Holding Company at Monterey Pop. After the festival, she was swiftly signed by Clive Davis.
item.description: The California event that defined the spirit of the Summer of Love, and gave Jimi Hendrix and Janis Joplin a boost, will rise again in June at 50.
item.dc:creator: BEN SISARIO
item.category: Big Brother and the Holding Co

item.title: What in the Name of Pop Is Going on With Eurovision?
item.media:description: The Russian singer Yulia Samoylova had been chosen to participate in the 2017 Eurovision Song Contest.
item.description: Geopolitics and pop culture clash as Ukraine bars Russia's entry into the 2017 Eurovision contest because of a visit by the contestant, Yulia Samoylova, to Crimea.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTOPHER D. SHEA

item.title: Revival for the Notekillers, Still Noisy After All These Years
item.media:description: David First, in his Brooklyn apartment, led the noise-rock band the Notekillers, who played the New York music scene in the late 1970s and early ‘80s.
item.media:credit: Demetrius Freeman for The New York Times
item.description: The unsung noise-rock band and its leader, David First, are somewhat closer to having a moment. Finally.
item.dc:creator: SARAH GRANT

item.title: Review: Renée Fleming’s Poignant Farewell to ‘Der Rosenkavalier’
item.media:description: Elina Garanca, left, as Octavian, and Renée Fleming as the Marschallin in Richard Strauss’s “Rosenkavalier” at the Metropolitan Opera.
item.description: This superstar soprano has been retiring her signature roles one by one, and however her career evolves, she should be proud of this magnificent performance at the Met.
item.dc:creator: ANTHONY TOMMASINI

item.title: Classical Music in NYC This Week
item.media:description: The violinist Anne Akiko Meyers at Carnegie Hall in 2014.
item.media:credit: Kevin Hagen for The New York Times
item.description: Our guide to the city’s best classical music and opera.
item.dc:creator: CORINNA da FONSECA-WOLLHEIM

item.title: Pop, Rock and Jazz in NYC This Week
item.media:description: From left, Ibrahim Ag Alhabib, Abdallah Ag Alhousseyni and Hassan Ag Touhami of the North African group Tinariwen.
item.description: Our guide to pop and rock shows and the best of live jazz.

item.title: When You Know It’s Love: Her Lyrics Move You
item.media:description: The singer and songwriter Andy Grammer and his wife, Aijia Grammer, also a singer.
item.description: A songwriter found love after agreeing to help a music school classmate compose a song for an ailing friend.
item.dc:creator: BROOKE LEA FOSTER

item.title: After a Soprano’s Crisis, a Brünnhilde Is Born
item.media:description: Christine Goerke blowing a kiss to the crowd during a curtain call in February after her performance as Brünnhilde in “Götterdämmerung” at the Canadian Opera Company.
item.media:credit: Cole Burston for The New York Times
item.description: Christine Goerke nearly quit opera after vocal troubles, but painstakingly remade herself into America’s reigning dramatic diva.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL COOPER

item.title: Review: The Chainsmokers Find That Pop Is an Awkward Fit
item.media:description: Alex Pall, left, and Drew Taggart of the Chainsmokers. Their debut album, “Memories…Do Not Open,” underscores the duo’s weaknesses and strengths.
item.description: Dance music’s inside jokesters suffer under the pop spotlight on “Memories…Do Not Open.”
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA

item.title: A Label That Fostered Mexican Cumbia Gets Its Own Shout-Out
item.media:description: Jorge Ariano, a D.J. known as Sonidero Rumbandela, recited a constant stream of shout-outs at a party celebrating the release of “¡Un Saludo! — Mexican Soundsystem Cumbia in LA.”
item.description: Discos Barba Azul, which operated until 2013, nurtured a massive cross-border underground. A new compilation collects and celebrates its recordings.
item.dc:creator: GREGORY SCRUGGS

item.title: An Opera About Robert Moses Is Among the River to River Festival Highlights
item.media:description: Maria Hassabi, left, and Hristoula Harakas in Ms. Hassabi’s “Show” at the River to River Festival in 2012. Ms. Hassabi’s work returns to the festival this year.
item.description: The Lower Manhattan Cultural Council has unveiled its lineup for the 16th annual festival of dance, music, theater and visual art.
item.dc:creator: JOSHUA BARONE

item.title: Anne Schwanewilms Performs Wolf and Strauss at Lincoln Center
item.media:description: The German soprano Anne Schwanewilms will perform at Alice Tully Hall on Sunday, April 16, with the pianist Malcolm Martineau.
item.description: This elusive German soprano will be accompanied by the eloquent pianist Malcolm Martineau.
item.dc:creator: CORINNA da FONSECA-WOLLHEIM

item.title: Ruff Ryders, Reunite! It’s Time for More Hip-Hop Nostalgia
item.media:description: DMX will perform as part of the Ruff Ryders reunion concert at Barclays Center.
item.media:credit: Emon Hassan for The New York Times
item.description: DMX, Eve, Swizz Beats, the Lox and more of the 1990s Yonkers crew will perform at Barclays Center.
item.dc:creator: JON CARAMANICA

item.title: Feature: The Return of Lorde
item.media:credit: Jack Davison for The New York Times
item.description: Four years after her debut album, the pop prodigy is back with a testimonial to heartbreak and solitude.
item.dc:creator: JONAH WEINER
